column4: My dad blames my wife for my problems
column6: Dad might not see it as blaming…
"Harsh" is an evaluation
"insulting" is an evaluation; what did dad actually say?
"Yells" is an evaluation
His anger is his own and he's making a judgment of you when he feels anger

column4: Jesse refuses to do his work
column6: Evaluation
Evaluation; hyperbole because no one can speak incessantly
Because I said so…
Implies wrongness or badness; maybe she sees herself as tired or easy-going!
Implies wrongness or badness
Implies wrongness or badness
Implies wrongness or badness

column4: He thinks only he has anything worth saying
column6: Infers what another person is thinking

column4: He wants to be the center of attention all the time
column6: Infers what another person is thinking
Includes evaluation
Evaluative connotations

column4: She won't get her work in
column6: Evaluative and implies / assumes rightness in that evaluation

column4: If you don't eat balanced meals, your health will be impaired
column6: Evaluative and confused prediction with certainty

column4: Minorities don't take care of their property
column6: Vague

column4: Hank Smith is a poor soccer player
column6: Denotes ability without indicating an evaluation is being made
Use of adverb or adjective in ways that do not signify an evaluation has been made
Mixed observation and evaluation; always exaggerates…

column4: She is never there when she's needed
column6: Mixed observation and evaluation; never exaggerates…

column4: You seldom do what I want
column6: Evaluation; seldom confuses observation and evaluation
Evaluation; frequently confuses observation and evaluation

column4: You're the most arrogant speaker we've ever had
column6: Evaluation

column4: John was angry with me yesterday for no reason
column6: "For no reason" is an evaluation; also it is an evaluation to infer that John was angry

column4: My father is a good man
column6: "Good man" is an evaluation!
"Too much"  is an evaluation
Aggressive is an evaluation

column4: My son often doesn't brush his teeth
column6: Often is an evaluation

column4: My aunt complains when I talk with her
column6: Complains is an evaluation

column4: He talked about war experiences instead of sticking to the agenda
column6: This is an observation!

column4: My father says my wife is responsible for my problems
column6: OK - this is an observation

column4: Lately my son is not doing his history homework
column6: OK - this is observable…
An observation way of saying someone is speaking loudly

column4: Jesse says no I don't want to do it
column6: Observation; simply repeating what Jesse said

column4: My husband doesn't tell me things that will affect me deeply
column6: Observation indicating a pattern of communication

column4: He talks louder than I would like
column6: Observation; owning your reaction

column4: He doesn't stay seated when I ask him to
column6: Because I said so…

column4: He sleeps between lunch and dinner
column6: Observation!

column4: He never ran while I watched him
column6: Observation!

column4: He did some things I didn't understand
column6: Observation!

column4: He did some things in ways I hadn't planned
column6: Observation!

column4: The principal told stories about his childhood during meetings, which led to meetings running 20 minutes overtime
column6: Observation!

column4: When I see you give all your lunch money to others I think you are being too generous
column6: Observation!

column4: Doug only studies for exams the night before
column6: Observation!

column4: If you don't eat balanced meals, I fear that your health my be impaired
column6: Observation with  feeling!

column4: I have not seen the minority family across the street shovel snow on their sidewalk
column6: Observation!

column4: Hank Smith has not scored a goal in 20 games
column6: Observation!

column4: Jim's looks don't appeal to me
column6: Observation!

column4: Whenever I have observed Jack on the phone, he has spoken for at least 30 minutes
column6: Observation!

column4: I cannot recall your ever writing to me
column6: Observation!

column4: The last three times I initiated an activity, you said you didn't want to do it
column6: Observation!

column4: He comes over at least three times a week
column6: Observation!

column4: John told me he was angry
column6: Observation!

column4: John pounded his fist on the table
column6: Observation!

column4: Yesterday evening Nancy bit her fingernails while watching television
column6: Observation!

column4: Sam didn't ask for my opinion during the meeting
column6: Observation!

column4: For the last 25 years my father has given one tenth of his salary to charity
column6: Observation!

column4: Janice spent over 60 hours at the office this week
column6: Observation!

column4: Henry hit his sister when she switched the television channel
column6: Observation!

column4: Pam was first in line every day this week
column6: Observation!

column4: Twice this week my son didn't brush his teeth before bed
column6: Observation!

column4: Luke told me I didn't look good in yellow
column6: Observation!

column4: My aunt called me three times this week, and each time talked about people who treated her in ways she didn't like
column6: Observation!
Yes/no question; not a request

column4: I want you to understand me
column6: "Understand" is not specific enough; instead say "tell me what you heard me say"

column4: I'd like you to feel more confidence in yourself
column6: Not specific enough; could say "I'd like you to take a course in assertiveness training…"

column4: I want you to stop drinking
column6: Saying what he/she doesn't want instead of what he/she wants

column4: I'd like you to let me be me
column6: Not specific enough; could say "I want you to tell me you won't leave our relationship"

column4: I'd like you to be honest with me about yesterday's meeting
column6: No specific enough; could say "I want you to tell me how you feel about what I did"

column4: I'd like to get to know you better
column6: Not specific enough; could say "I'd like you to tell me if you would be willing to meet for lunch once a week"

column4: I would like you to show respect for my privacy
column6: Not specific enough; could say "I'd like you to agree to knock before you enter my office"

column4: I'd like you to prepare supper more often
column6: Not specific enough; could say "I'd like you to prepare supper every Monday"

column4: Are you using the word love as a feeling?
column6: Because I said so…

column4: Could you tell  me what you want me to do to meet your need for love
column6: Request

column4: I'd like you to tell me one thing that I did that you appreciate
column6: Request

column4: I would like you to drive at or below the speed limit
column6: Request

column4: you disappointed me by not coming over last evening
column6: Attributes responsibility for the disappointment soley to the action of the other person

column4: Their cancelling the contract really irritated me
column6: Attributes irritation soley to the behavior of the other party

column4: It hurts Mommy and Daddy when you get poor grades at school
column6: Implies child's actions are the cause of the parents' happiness or unhappiness

column4: It really infuriates me when spelling mistakes appear in our public brochures
column6: Impersonal pronouns such as "it" mask accountability for our own feelings
Impersonal pronouns such as "that" mask accountability for our own feelings

column4: When you don't call me on my birthday, I feel hurt
column6: Statements that mention only the actions of others may mask accountability for our own feelings

column4: Mommy is disappointed when you don't finishe your food
column6: Statements that mention only the actions of others may mask accountability for our own feelings

column4: I feel hurt because you said you don't love me
column6: Use of expression "I feel (emotion) because…" followed by a person or pronoun other than "I" may mask accountability for own feelings

column4: I feel angry because the supervisor broke her promise
column6: Use of expression "I feel (emotion) because…" followed by a person or pronoun other than "I" may mask accountability for own feelings
Judgment of others; really tells us that their need to be understood is not being fulfilled

column4: you love your work more that you love me
column6: Judgment of others; really saying need for intimacy is not being met

column4: you irritate me when you leave company documents on the conference room floor
column6: Implies other person's behavior is responsible for speaker's feelings

column4: I was disappointed when you didn't come over because I wanted to talk over some things that were bothering me
column6: The feeling of disappointment is traced to the speaker's own desire that was not being fulfilled

column4: When they cancelled the contract, I felt really irritated because I was thinking to myself that it was an awfully irresponsible thing to do
column6: Accepts responsibility for feeling by acknowledging the thought behind it

column4: When they cancelled the contract, I felt really irritated because I was hoping for an opportunity to re-hire the workers we laid off last year
column6: Accepts responsibility for feeling and connects it to the need or desire

column4: I feel really infuriated when spelling mistakes like that appear in our public brochures because I want our company to project a professional image
column6: Connects feeling to need and acknowledges own responsibility

column4: I feels disappointed when you don't finish your food, because I want you to grow up strong and healthy
column6: Connects feeling to need and acknowledges own responsibility

column4: I feel angry that the supervisor broke her promise, because I was counting on getting that long weekend to visit my brother
column6: Connects feeling to need and acknowledges own responsibility

column4: I'm irritated when you leave company documents on the conference room floor because I want our documents to be safely stored and accessible
column6: Expresses feeling and links to need

column4: I feel angry when you say that because I am wanting respect and I hear your words as an insult
column6: Acknowledges responsibility for feelings

column4: I'm sad that you won't be coming for dinner because I was hoping we could spend the evening together
column6: Acknowledges responsibility for feelings

column4: I'm discouraged because I would have liked to have progressed further in my work by now
column6: Acknowledges responsibility for feelings

column4: I am grateful that you offered me a ride because I was needing to get home before my children
column6: Acknowledges responsibility for feelings
